[GAME] You are Player 0 in a 2-player Texas Hold'em Poker game.
Your goal is to win chips and outlast opponents through strategic play.
Game Information:
- 10 hands total
- Starting stack: 1000 chips
- Blinds: 10/20

Here are examples of good poker decision-making:

Example 1: Pre-flop with pocket aces (A♠ A♥), facing a small bet. Action: '[Raise 50]' because pocket aces are the strongest starting hand and should be played aggressively to build the pot.

Example 2: You have 7♣ 2♦ (worst starting hand) and opponent bets big. Action: '[Fold]' because this hand has almost no chance of winning and continuing would waste chips.

Example 3: You have a strong flush draw on the flop, opponent checks, pot is 100 chips. Action: '[Bet 40]' to take control and potentially win immediately, or build pot for when you complete your draw.

Example 4: You're short on chips (only 200 left) and have A♠ K♦ facing a big raise. Action: '[Call]' or '[Raise 200]' all-in because AK is strong enough to risk your tournament life with a short stack.

Available actions (exact tokens):
  '[Check]'  - when no bet is live
  '[Call]'   - match the current bet
  '[Fold]'   - discard your hand
  '[Bet N]'  - open for N chips
  '[Raise N]'- raise by N chips

Invalid actions will result in retries. Use exact bracket format and ensure you have sufficient chips for bets/raises. Check when facing a bet is invalid.

rounds.response:
Action: [Fold]

A Q4 offsuit is one of the weakest hands in Hold’em. From the small blind (where I’ve already posted 20 of the 30-chip pot), I’m out of position and have nothing that justifies putting in additional chips. Folding saves chips for better spots.

rounds.response:
My hole cards 5♠ 7♥ are very weak, only forming the speculative “75 suited” if both were spades—here they’re offsuit. A 3-bet pot out of position multiplies that weakness. Facing a 3-× raise (to 60) with a trash hand 50 BB deep, continuing is just lighting chips on fire.

[Fold]

- I'm the small blind (SB) this hand with 1010 chips
- Hole cards: A♠ 4♣ - a moderately strong hand with an ace
- Current situation: Pot is 30, I need to call 20 to see the flop

With A4 offsuit in the small blind, this is a decent hand that plays well against a single opponent. While my kicker (4) is weak, the ace alone has significant value heads-up. Given that we've seen Player 0 play somewhat aggressively (they raised to 60 with position earlier), calling here is reasonable to see the flop and potentially outplay them post-flop.

[Call]

rounds.response:
I have A♠ 4♣, which is a decent hand—ace-high with a wheel (A-2-3-4-5) draw potential. The pot is 100 chips now, I’ve already called 20, and it’ll cost 60 more (total of 80) to continue.  

Against a single opponent, A4 can be good, especially since my ace kicker beats a lot of ace-x hands. If I just call, the pot will be 180 chips and I’ll have 930 behind; if I hit any ace on the flop I’ll be ahead of most non-paired ranges and can win a bigger pot.  

I choose to continue with [Call].

rounds.response:
I'm holding A♠ 4♣. The board now reads 4⋄ 3♥ J♣ Q♥, giving me bottom-pair (a pair of 4’s) with an ace.  
P0 just showed a lot of strength by raising the flop from 110 to 150 and now checks the turn. This line often indicates either a semi-bluff that didn’t improve or a very strong hand giving up initiative, but with a J and Q now out there my hand is only mediocre. If I bet I might get value from some weaker jacks/queens or draws, but I risk facing another big raise that would commit me with a marginal holding.

With the pot already 460 chips and 800 effective behind, checking back keeps the pot small and protects my mid-strength hand; I can try to realize my equity on the river, especially when the opponent elects not to continue aggression. No compelling reason to build a monster pot with one pair. I check.

[Check]

rounds.response:
I hold A♠ 4♣, giving me two-pair (A♠ 4♣ 4♦ J♣ J♦).  
The river completes no possible flush draw, and my two-pair vs. the paired board puts me ahead of all un-paired opponents and behind only a jack (trips J), queen (full house), or slow-played pocket pair >4.

Pot: 460. No bet is live. I am closing the action out of position.

Because  
- my hand strength is strong but not nutted,  
- a value-bet can get paid by any queen or jack,  
- but I block some 4x, and opponent checked back turn after I called flop,  

I’ll bet thin for value: ~55 % pot.

[Bet 250]
